title: How to Dry Bay Leaves

steps.headline: Lay 1 or 2 paper towels onto a baking sheet.
steps.description: Use a baking sheet large enough to accommodate all of the bay leaves so they’re not touching. Make sure you have enough paper towels to cover the sheet, but you don’t need more than a single layer.

steps.headline: Spread the bay leaves onto the paper towels.
steps.description: Don’t layer the leaves on top of each other, let them have their own space to ensure that they dry evenly. If you have a lot of bay leaves, use another baking sheet. Don’t mix bay leaves with other herbs because they’ll have different drying times.

steps.headline: Place the baking sheet in a warm, dry room that has plenty of ventilation.
steps.description: Your kitchen counter or table is the perfect spot. Just make sure the leaves aren’t exposed to direct sunlight because it will cause the leaves to wilt and brown. Indirect sunlight is okay, but not ideal.

steps.headline: Check on the leaves after 1 week and flip them over.
steps.description: Flipping the leaves will allow each one to dry evenly and at the same pace. If some leaves appear to be drying faster than others, take note of that and check on the drier ones in another 3 to 4 days.

steps.headline: Let them dry for 1 more week.
steps.description: Notice whether there is any remaining moisture left in the leaves. If they are still dark green in spots or soft, they may need another 3 to 4 days or 1 full week to dry. If some of the leaves are already dry, remove them and store them in an airtight container.

steps.headline: Strip the leaves away from the stems and store them in an airtight container.
steps.description: Discard the stem and store the whole leaves in a plastic zipper bag or airtight container. You can also crush them if you don’t plan to use whole leaves at a time in your recipes. Keep them in a cool, dark place at a temperature between 65°F (18°C) and 75°F (24°C). To crush or grind the leaves, break them apart with your fingers and crush each larger piece with the back of a spoon until you have a coarse, sandy texture. Alternatively, you can crush them into a fine powder using a mortar and pestle. Whole leaves will retain their flavor and aroma longer than crushed leaves. When stored properly, dried bay leaves will last for up to 1 year.

steps.headline: Preheat your dehydrator to 95°F (35°C) to 115°F (46°C).
steps.description: Set your dehydrator to 95°F (35°C) to 115°F (46°C) and let it heat up for about 30 minutes. Set it to 125°F (51°C) if you live in an area with high humidity. Refer to your dehydrator’s user manual to see if it offers suggested temperatures for drying bay leaves.

steps.headline: Rinse the bay leaves under a cool, gentle stream of water.
steps.description: Turn on your faucet to a low level of water pressure and hold the leaves in your hands. Gently massage the leaves to remove any dust and debris. Gather a bushel of the leaves and gently shake off as much of the water as possible and pat them dry with a paper towel. You can also put the herbs in a colander and stir it around with your fingers. Let them dry fully for about 1 to 2 hours before putting them in the dehydrator.

steps.headline: Arrange the herbs on dehydrator trays in a single layer.
steps.description: Make sure the herbs are not touching or overlapping in any way to prevent uneven drying. If your dehydrator has multiple shelves, use a second dehydrator tray if you need to. If your dehydrator has several stacked shelves, the top shelf is going to be the coolest and take more time to dry the herbs. Slide the tray into the bottom shelf for a faster drying time.

steps.headline: Allow the herbs to dry for 1 to 4 hours, checking on them each hour.
steps.description: Bay leaves can take anywhere from 1 to 4 hours to dry depending on your dehydrator and the level of humidity in the air. If they’re not brittle and crispy after 1 hour, leave them in for another 30 minutes to an hour before checking again. Consult the instruction booklet that came with your dehydrator to see if it offers any suggested drying times.

steps.headline: Remove the dried leaves from the dehydrator and let them cool.
steps.description: You will know they have completed drying when they begin to curl or crumble and the stems start to split. Leave the tray on the kitchen counter to cool for 1 hour. Avoid exposing the dried herbs to direct sunlight while they’re cooling.

steps.headline: Remove the stems and store the dried leaves in an airtight bag or container.
steps.description: Carefully separate the leaves from the stems. Storing the leaves whole will retain the most flavor, but you can go ahead and crush them if you don’t plan to use the whole leaves in your recipes. Store them in a cool, dark place at a temperature between 65°F (18°C) and 75°F (24°C). Toss the stems into your garden or compost them.

methods.name: Drying Bay Leaves in the Oven

steps.headline: Set your oven to the lowest heat setting.
steps.description: If your oven goes as low as 90°F (32°C) to 110°F (43°C), that’s perfect! If not, set it to the lowest temperature and leave the door slightly open for the whole process. Alternatively, if your oven has a warm setting or if you have a separate warmer, use that instead. Drying bay leaves at temperatures above 110°F (43°C) will result in flavor loss, so it’s important to crack the oven door if your oven is too hot. If you leave the oven door cracked open, make sure there are no pets or children in the area.

steps.headline: Place the bay leaves onto a baking sheet.
steps.description: Use a clean baking sheet that’s large enough to accommodate all of the leaves. Place them so each leaf has at least ⁄4 inch (0.64 cm) of room to ensure even drying. Make sure the baking sheet has no oils or non-stick sprays on it because that will inhibit the drying process.

steps.headline: Place the baking sheet on the lowest rack of your oven.
steps.description: The rack closest to the heating element is the best location for browning and crisping. In this case, you want the bay leaves to be nice and crispy. If your oven has known cool or hot spots, be prepared to rotate the tray during the drying process. Take out any other baking sheets that might be in your oven because they’ll affect the heat and air circulation.

steps.headline: Leave them in the oven for 30 minutes before flipping the leaves.
steps.description: Turn each bay leaf over to ensure each one gets dried evenly. Use oven mitts to carefully remove the baking tray from the oven or to slide it out so you don’t have to put your hand inside the oven. Grab each leaf by the stem and carefully flip them over. If you’re leaving the door open, rotate the entire tray so the leaves that were toward the front of the oven are now toward the back.

steps.headline: Wait 45 minutes before checking the leaves for dryness.
steps.description: Wear an oven mitt to slide the tray out of the oven and use your fingers to feel each leaf. If you can bend the leaves without them breaking, leave them in the oven for an additional 15 to 30 minutes before checking again. If the leaves are brittle and break apart when you touch them, take them out and let them cool on the counter.

steps.headline: Turn off the oven once they’re crispy and dry.
steps.description: Drying bay leaves in the oven typically takes around 1 hour, but it could take longer if you live in a humid environment. Once they’re dry, shut the oven off and let them cool on the tray for about 1 hour. If the leaves look discolored and feel extremely brittle, turn off the oven and use oven mitts to transfer the tray to the countertop so they can dry without added heat.

steps.headline: Pull off the stems and store the leaves in a sealed container or zipper bag.
steps.description: Pull the stems away from the leaves and toss them into your garden or compost bin. Transfer the leaves into an airtight container or zipper bag. When stored properly, dried bay leaves will keep their flavor for years! You can use dried bay leaf for up to 3 years, but their flavor and scent will diminish over time. You can crush the leaves right away, but they’ll lose their flavor faster. If you’re cooking right away, go ahead and use them—just note that a little bay leaf goes a long way!

steps.headline: Line a microwavable plate with a paper towel.
steps.description: Do not use paper towels made from recycled paper because they contain small fragments of metal that might ignite in the microwave. You can also use a clean kitchen towel. If you use a kitchen towel, make sure it doesn’t contain any metal tags as these can ignite in the microwave.

steps.headline: Place the leaves onto the towel before covering them with another towel.
steps.description: Lay the bay leaves onto the paper towel so none of them are touching. Then cover them with another paper towel. If you’re using a large kitchen cloth, fold it over instead of using a separate towel to cover them.

steps.headline: Microwave the leaves on high power for 35 to 45 seconds.
steps.description: Bay leaves contain lots of oil, so they need adequate time to dry out but not so much that they’re burned. Setting it to 35 seconds is recommended for standard (1000 watt) microwaves. Depending on your microwaves, cut the time down to 30 seconds or increase it to 50 seconds. Don’t microwave the leaves for over 70 or 80 seconds—they’ll probably burn!

steps.headline: Separate the stems from the leaves and store them in an airtight container.
steps.description: The bay leaves are fully dried when they’re crisp and brittle. If they still feel soft or if they can bend without breaking, microwave them 10 to 20 seconds at a time before checking again. If your bay leaves are brown and smell burned, toss them and try it again with a fresh batch. Whole bay leaves retain their flavor longer than crushed bay leaves.

Don’t mix bay leaves with other herbs because they’ll have different drying times. Place the baking sheet in a warm, dry room that has plenty of ventilation. Your kitchen counter or table is the perfect spot. Just make sure the leaves aren’t exposed to direct sunlight because it will cause the leaves to wilt and brown. Indirect sunlight is okay, but not ideal. Check on the leaves after 1 week and flip them over. Flipping the leaves will allow each one to dry evenly and at the same pace. Notice whether there is any remaining moisture left in the leaves. If they are still dark green in spots or soft, they may need another 3 to 4 days or 1 full week to dry. If they’re not brittle and crispy after 1 hour, leave them in for another 30 minutes to an hour before checking again. Consult the instruction booklet that came with your dehydrator to see if it offers any suggested drying times. Remove the dried leaves from the dehydrator and let them cool. Storing the leaves whole will retain the most flavor, but you can go ahead and crush them if you don’t plan to use the whole leaves in your recipes. Store them in a cool, dark place at a temperature between 65°F (18°C) and 75°F (24°C). Toss the stems into your garden or compost them.
